_meta.purpose: Ensure fair compensation and protection for all contributors through evidence-based economic governance
_meta.description: Ethical principles for labor rights and fair compensation, extending core principles.
_meta.note: All core locked principles automatically apply. Domain principles add specificity. Principles reference terms via 'uses_terms'.

@protection_ratchet.statement: Rights, tokens, and compensation once distributed can never be taken back. Power and value may flow outward, but never consolidate inward.
@protection_ratchet.lock_reason: Prevents elite formation, power consolidation, and retroactive value extraction. Mathematical protection against governance capture.
application: Earned tokens cannot be retroactively reduced or diluted without consent
Granted rights cannot be revoked without 99% consensus
Compensation promises are binding once made
Power distribution can only become more equal, never less
@protection_ratchet.rationale: The cost of allowing power consolidation far exceeds the cost of permanent decentralization.

@labor_primacy.statement: Labor evidence (contribution, effort, output, skill) always supersedes tradition, economic convenience, or preference in determining fair compensation and governance weight.
@labor_primacy.lock_reason: Prevents rationalization of exploitation through non-economic justifications.
implications: Tradition is not justification for underpayment
Market rate does not define fair compensation if it exploits
Only verifiable contribution can inform reward allocation
@labor_primacy.application: When tradition/economics conflict with proven contribution â†’ contribution wins

@contribution_axiom.statement: Entities capable of providing value deserve fair compensation. Capacity to contribute is the relevant criterion, not status, background, or negotiating power.
@contribution_axiom.lock_reason: Defines who counts as a protected stakeholder in this domain.
implications: Compensation must be proportional regardless of stakeholder type
Negotiating power does not determine fair share
Capital contribution is valued but constrained by labor contribution
@contribution_axiom.source: Rooted in labor value theory and cooperative economics

@five_rights_principle.statement: All contributors in the system deserve, at minimum, the Five Labor Rights. Violation of any right constitutes an exploitation concern.
@five_rights_principle.rationale: Established baseline for contributor protection worldwide.
@five_rights_principle.application: Practices must be evaluated against all five rights
@five_rights_principle.evolution_note: Rights may be extended but not reduced per @protection_asymmetry.

@proportionality.statement: The severity of harm to contributors must be weighed against the necessity and magnitude of benefit. Trivial benefits cannot justify significant exploitation.
application: Essential system survival may justify temporary reduced compensation with safeguards
Investor convenience does not justify worker exploitation
Profit maximization does not justify harm
Efficiency gains must be shared proportionally

examples.justified: Temporary salary reduction during existential crisis, with transparent recovery plan and proportional sacrifice
examples.not_justified: Executive bonuses while workers laid off, algorithmic wage suppression for margin, unpaid overtime for convenience

@individual_consideration.statement: Each individual contributor's welfare matters, not just aggregate or average metrics.
@individual_consideration.rationale: Exploitation is experienced by individuals, not abstractions.
implications: One contributor's underpayment is not offset by another's overpayment
System growth does not reduce individual protection
Edge cases deserve consideration, not dismissal

@continuous_improvement.statement: Current compensation standards are minimum baselines, not endpoints. We commit to continuously improving contributor welfare as the system grows.
@continuous_improvement.rationale: What is acceptable today may be recognized as exploitative tomorrow.
implications: Standards should improve over time, never regress
New evidence of exploitation triggers review
Better alternatives should replace worse ones
System success must translate to contributor success
